Pep Rally Post-Mortem:
The disappointing failure of
last Friday's Booster Club pep
rally has caused sharp concern
among Hopkins enthusiasts. The
rally was doomed to failure, as a
rousing twenty to thirty people
appeared at the appointed time
and place.
Jeff Robinson, Booster Club
president, minimized the culpability of his organization for the
dismal failure explaining that it
had neglected only to make an
announcement at the freshman
football game. He attributed the
poor attendance to lack of student interest, declaring, "The
student body should be ashamed
that they don't care enough to
for
more enthusiasm
show
events."
Too Sophisticated
Mr. Marshall Turner, director

of athletic events, suggested that
Hopkins students had just become too sophisticated to be enthusiastic about any sporting
event. He charged that even the
dormitory student riots show lack
of interest and purpose, as they
are solely motivated by the desire
to "fool around." He commended
the Booster Club for having done
as good a job as possible under
the circumstances.

DSRC Bogs Down
In Consideration
Of Judicial Board
By DAVE QUEEN
Work on the establishment of
a Judicial Board of the DSRC
was temporarily bogged down
last Tuesday evening as the
Council came into conflict over
the wording of the new proposals for the Constitution. The
wording was prepared by the
Constitutional Committee. Several aspects of the proposed
wording were not approved be.
cause of their implications.
Sam Olson, chairman of the
Judiciary Committee, which first
drew hp the new proposals, asserted that the changes which
needed to be made in the wording were only minor ones.
The revisions, as read by Bill
Young, Constitutional Committee
Chairman, stated that the Judicial Board would be "self-perpetuating," that members of the
Board, once elected, would re-.
main on the Board as long as
they remained in the dormitories,
and that the secretary of the
Board would be selected front
the dormitory students.
The Council decided that the
Board would be "self-perpetuating" since it would be elected
by the DSRC. Members of the
Council disagreed with the permanence of membership on the
Board; the DSRC is to elect
members every spring.
The
Council also asserted that "a
secretary from the DSRC" was
to be Recorder at the trials.
In short, the Constitutional
Committee did not say what the
Committee
Judiciary
wanted
said; this was so because the

"Operation Crossroads Africa"
sponsored by the State Department of the United States, will be
conducted on Saturday, Nov. 18,
in Washington, D.C. This conference for college students will
focus attention on the economic,
international, social, educational,
and cultural needs of the emerging African nations. Speakers
and leaders of this conference
will represent African governments, the State Department,
and international business organizations. Those interested in the
vital African problem should apply to box 2133.

'Prodigal' Opens
Playshop's 41st
Season Tonite
"The Prodigal" by Jack Richardson will open the Playshop's
41st season, playing for eight
performances — November 9-12,
and 16-19, at 8:30 P .M., at the
Barn on Homewood campus.
With "The Prodigal," his first
produced play, Jack Richardson
realized an instant critical and
popular success during the 1960
off-Broadway season. The basic
theme of "The Prodigal" is the
great Orestes legend dealing with
idealism, political opportunism
and bloody vengeance.
Included in the cast of this
Maryland premiere are: Buzz
Schloss, Bill Bevans, Shirley
Herrmann, Joseph
Bandiera,
Edythe Dorsey, Daniel King, Bea
Saks, Emmy Lee Butler, Barbara
Brown, Jim Curry, Tom Savin
and Rick Coburn. The director
of the production is Frances
Carey Bowen assisted by Lester
Wolf.
Student tickets are 75 cents
when purchased in advance at
the Playshop office, Gilman 6.

Bards To Open
Fall Season
With Winterset
Rehearsels have begun for the
Barnstormers' fall play, Winterset, by Maxwell Anderson. Inspired by the Sacco-Vanzetti
case, Winterset is the haunting
drama concerning a young man's
attempt to clear the name of his
father, who was unjustly found
guilty of a crime that he did not
commit. Leading roles have been
assigned to Pete Grossman, Judy
Blank, Mike Sundermeyer, Burt
Routman, Bob Landau, Kostia
Bergman, and Richard Estaveez.
Bob Dunn Jr., who has directed
many productions for Loyola
College, will be in charge of staging the production.

IFC To Release
Academic Scores
To News-Letter
The IFC this week held an extended debate on whether or not
to release the academic averages
of the fraternities to the public.
Don Steiner, President of the
IFC, informed the representatives
that the registrar would not release the averages until permission was granted by the IFC.
Steiner suggested that some
fraternities might find this "embarrassing" and added that they
need not be released if certain
fraternities objected. Problems
that might arise from such a release concern the possibility that
nationals could misinterpret the
figures. Also considered was the
fact that fraternity men who
flunked out last year are included in the average. Other
fraternities pointed out that it
was just as embarrassing when
athletic averages were released.
After a lengthy debate, the
IFC voted to release the averages
to the nationals and the NewsLOW.

during the football games. And in the past the Booster
Club has made efforts to arouse the campus from its
apathy. But, in all fairness, the fiasco of last week's
aborted pep rally was not wholly due to student apathy.
As a wise sage once commented "it ain't what you
do, but the way you do it." And the pep rally was a
perfect example of inept planning anti execution. Publicity for the event was little or non-existent and no
announcement was made at the freshman football game.
But the concept of bow and when to hold the pep
rally was the true cause of its failure. In the first place
it is doubtful that even the most rabid Hopkins rooter
derives any thrill from seeing football players parade
past the stands or hearing the coach make several
cautious remarks about the probability of winning
tomorrow's game. The essence of a pep rally is just
what the name implies, pep.
The ingredients of a sucessful pep rally include a
scene of confusion and noise, a band, a lion-fire, songs,
and people yelling, shouting anti having fun. Basically
it is a controlled riot with the avowed purpose of cheering
on the team's stalwarts and,.the real purpose of letting go
A pep rally which does not
and having some fun.
approximate this type of situation is doomed to failure.
It would appear that the Booster Club planned this
pep rally only so that it could say that it tried. But the fact
is that the Booster Club did not try. Thus last week's
flop is not a reflection on the student body so much as
it is an indication of the capabilities of the 'Booster Club.

PEP Rally?
Now that the furor over the eligibility of a certain
freshman petition has died down it might be wise to
examine the nature anti cause of the complaints.
In the first place we note that hardly an election
goes by without some confusion over the rules or the
legality of various petitions. This regularity of complaints indicates that, at the very least, a clarification of
election rules is necessary and that such a clarification
should well precede the next election. The Student Council action on this matter was well advised and is a step
in the right direction.
Secondly, it is not apparent why the SAC is in any
way connected with election procedures. It would seem
obvious that this is the sole responsibility of the Student
Council.
The third and most important poin to be noted is
the place fraternity politics can be accused of playing in
the election procedures. The confusion this year is a
ease in point. A freshman's petition for vice president
of his class was refused, first on the grounds of being
seconds late. When the absurdity of this situation was
pointed out, the same petition was rejected for having
one too few signatures even though this shortage was not
the fault of the freshman.
Taking into account the fact that if this petition had
been refused, only one candidate, a member of Phi
Epsilon Pi, would run for the office and the fact that the
petition was refused on the above stated flimsy grounds
by a member of the same fraternity, it is apparent how
such a charge of fraternity politics could be made.
Whether this was, indeed, an instance of fraternity
politics or not is beside the point. What matters is tfiat
such an issue could arise in the first place. It would
seem that our student government could he run in such
a manner that (+rages of this nature would not arise.

It is no disgrace to be poor. It is an error, but it is no disgrace.
So if your purse is empty, do not skulk and brood and hide
your head in shame. Stand tall. Admit your poverty. Admit it
freely and frankly and all kinds of good things will happen to
you. Take, for instance, the case of Blossom Sigafoos.
Blossom, an impecunious freshman at an Eastern girls'
college, was smart as a whip and round as a dumpling, and
scarcely a day went by when she didn't get invited to a party
weekend at one of the nearby men's schools.'But Blossom never
accepted. She did not have the rail fare; she did not have the
clothes. Weekend after weekend, while her classmates went
frolicking, Blossom sat alone, saved from utter despair only
by her pack of Marlboros, for even an exchequer as slian as
Blossom's can afford the joys of Marlboro—joys far beyond
their paltry price: rich, mellow.tobaccos, lovingly cured and
carefully packed, and an exclusive selectrate filter. Croesus
himself could not,buy a better cigarette!
However, Marlboro's most passionate admirers—among
whose number I am paid to count myself—would not claim that
Marlboro can entirely replace love and romance, and Blossom
/grew steadily moroser.

Then one day came a phone call from an intelligent sophomore named Tom O'Shanter at a nearby men's college. "Blossom," said Tom,"I want you to come down next week for the
barley festival, and I won't take no for an answer.!!
"No," said Blossom.
"Foolish girl," said Tom gently. "I know why you refuse
me. It is because you are poor, isn't it?"
"Yes;' said Blossom.
"I will send you a railroad ticket," said Tom. "Also a hardboiled egg in case you get hungry on the train."
"But I have nothing to wear," said Blossom.
Tom replied,"I will send you one suit of cashmere, two gowns
of lace, three slacks of velvet, four shoes of calf, five socks of
nylon, and a partridge in a pear tree."
"That is most kind," said Blossom, "but I fear I cannot
dance and enjoy myself while back home my poor lame brother
Tiny Tim lies abed."
"Send him to Mayo Brothers and put it on my tab,"said Tom.
"You are terribly decent," said Blossom, "but I cannot
come to your party because all the other girls at the party
will be from rich, distinguished families, and my father is but
a humble woodcutter."
"I will buy him Yosemite," said Tom.
"You have a great heart," said Blossom. "Hold the phone
while I ask our wise and kindly old Dean of Women whether it
is proper for me to accept all these gifts."
She went forthwith and asked the Dean of Women, and the
Dean of Women laid her wise and kindly old band on Blossom's
cheek and said,"Child, let not false pride rob you of happiness.
Accept these gifts from Tom."
"Oh, bless you, Wise and Kindly," breathed Blossom,
dropping grateful tears into the Dean's reticule. "I must run
and tell Tom."
"Yes, run, child," said thc Dean, a smile wrinkling her wise
and kindly old eyes."And ask him has he got an older brother."

Make no mistake about it. Ayn
Rand's recent incendiary speech
detonated a thermonuclear shock
wave of conservatism that may
only subside when Barry Goldwater becomes President. The
conservative tide is making an
attempt to erode that awesome
bank of apathy which has immersed the Hopkins' man since
the days of the great transition
from Wilson to Harding. William
Buckley, articulate editor of the
National Review, will doubtless
abet the movement with a visit
in the spring. The fledgling "Conservative Association" is at the
present time merely a reflection
of the new interest but is striving for a commanding role in the
reawakening of the right.

There's not much you can be
sure of nowadays. Steady Sam
Rayburn is fading fast; we're
threatened by nuclear war; and
now, of all things, Hopkins is
starting to win in Cross Country.
The Jays had a tidy 0-6 record
going into Saturday's triangular
meet with Swarthmore and Dickinson, but managed to outscore
the latter and finish second.
Then this Tuesday the runners
pulled another about-face and
trounced Washington College 19•
36.
Wins "Marred" Record
Although the nasty wins marred a previously unblemished log,
coach George Brown and his boys
breathed a sigh of relief. After
all, you can't keep up that sort
of amazing performance forever.
The harriers will travel to
Chester, Pa., tomorrow afternoon
to face Pennsylvania Military
Academy and Elizabethtown in
the final team meet of the season. Since the Jays have already
"ruined" things with two messy
wins, another won't hurt, so
things should prove to be fairly
interesting.
Impressive Showing
Tuesday's performance was
unquestionably the most impressive of the season, with Gerry
Miller, team captain Jim Fitzpatrick, and Steve Haust capturing the first three places. All
three runners have placed well
throughout most of the campaign, but this was the first time
that they have combined their
successful efforts in the same
meet.
The Mason-Dixon season will

come to a close next Saturday with the running of the
championships
at
individual
Washington College. Not much
is expected from the Hopkins
entries in that event.
The freshman harriers have already completed their season,
finishing in a blaze of glory with
a victory over Bainbridge Prep.

Cats are notoriously silent in their singularly feline way. But even the
most stealthily treading tomcat could take lessons from the men at
Ford Motor Company whose job it is to track down and suppress
unwanted noise in vehicles,.
At our Ford Research and Engineering Center in Dearborn, engineers
have created a unique room without echoes, virtually duplicating the
perfect stillness that exists miles above the earth's surface.
The "Silent Room", as we call it, is a chamber utilizing fiber-glass
wedges as sonic "blotters" to soak up noise emanating from subjects
undergoing developmental tests. In this acoustically sterile environ•.
ment, electronic instruments seek out the source of vibrations,
rattles, rumbles and squeaks so that they can be eliminated in
production.
This scientific approach to silence is but a tiny facet of the manysided program of pure and "applied research which goes on daily at
Ford Motor Company. It is another example of ford's leadership
through scientific research and engineering.

DSRC Bogs Down
In Consideration
Of Judicial Board
By DAVE QUEEN
Work on the establishment of
a Judicial Board of the DSRC
was temporarily bogged down
last Tuesday evening as the
Council came into conflict over
the wording of the new proposals for the Constitution. The
wording was prepared by the
Constitutional Committee. Several aspects of the proposed
wording were not approved be.
cause of their implications.
Sam Olson, chairman of the
Judiciary Committee, which first
drew hp the new proposals, asserted that the changes which
needed to be made in the wording were only minor ones.
The revisions, as read by Bill
Young, Constitutional Committee
Chairman, stated that the Judicial Board would be "self-perpetuating," that members of the
Board, once elected, would re-.
main on the Board as long as
they remained in the dormitories,
and that the secretary of the
Board would be selected front
the dormitory students.
The Council decided that the

'Prodigal' Opens
Playshop's 41st
Season Tonite
"The Prodigal" by Jack Richardson will open the Playshop's
41st season, playing for eight
performances — November 9-12,
and 16-19, at 8:30 P .M., at the
Barn on Homewood campus.
With "The Prodigal," his first
produced play, Jack Richardson
realized an instant critical and
popular success during the 1960
off-Broadway season. The basic
theme of "The Prodigal" is the
great Orestes legend dealing with
idealism, political opportunism
and bloody vengeance.
Included in the cast of this
Maryland premiere are: Buzz
Schloss, Bill Bevans, Shirley
Herrmann, Joseph
Bandiera,
Edythe Dorsey, Daniel King, Bea
Saks, Emmy Lee Butler, Barbara
Brown, Jim Curry, Tom Savin
and Rick Coburn. The director
of the production is Frances
Carey Bowen assisted by Lester
Wolf.
Student tickets are 75 cents
when purchased in advance at
the Playshop office, Gilman 6.

Bards To Open
Fall Season
With Winterset
Rehearsels have begun for the
Barnstormers' fall play, Winterset, by Maxwell Anderson. Inspired by the Sacco-Vanzetti
case, Winterset is the haunting
drama concerning a young man's
attempt to clear the name of his
father, who was unjustly found
guilty of a crime that he did not
commit. Leading roles have been
assigned to Pete Grossman, Judy
Blank, Mike Sundermeyer, Burt
Routman, Bob Landau, Kostia
Bergman, and Richard Estaveez.
Bob Dunn Jr., who has directed
many productions for Loyola
College, will be in charge of staging the production.

IFC To Release
Academic Scores
To News-Letter
The IFC this week held an extended debate on whether or not
to release the academic averages
of the fraternities to the public.
Don Steiner, President of the
IFC, informed the representatives
that the registrar would not release the averages until permission was granted by the IFC.
Steiner suggested that some
fraternities might find this "embarrassing" and added that they
need not be released if certain
fraternities objected. Problems
that might arise from such a release concern the possibility that
nationals could misinterpret the
figures. Also considered was the
fact that fraternity men who
flunked out last year are included in the average. Other
fraternities pointed out that it
was just as embarrassing when
athletic averages were released.
After a lengthy debate, the
IFC voted to release the averages
to the nationals and the NewsLOW.

PEP Rally?
Now that the furor over the eligibility of a certain
freshman petition has died down it might be wise to
examine the nature anti cause of the complaints.
In the first place we note that hardly an election
goes by without some confusion over the rules or the
legality of various petitions. This regularity of complaints indicates that, at the very least, a clarification of
election rules is necessary and that such a clarification
should well precede the next election. The Student Council action on this matter was well advised and is a step
in the right direction.
Secondly, it is not apparent why the SAC is in any
way connected with election procedures. It would seem
obvious that this is the sole responsibility of the Student
Council.
The third and most important poin to be noted is
the place fraternity politics can be accused of playing in
the election procedures. The confusion this year is a
ease in point. A freshman's petition for vice president
of his class was refused, first on the grounds of being
seconds late. When the absurdity of this situation was
pointed out, the same petition was rejected for having
one too few signatures even though this shortage was not
the fault of the freshman.
Taking into account the fact that if this petition had
been refused, only one candidate, a member of Phi
Epsilon Pi, would run for the office and the fact that the
petition was refused on the above stated flimsy grounds
by a member of the same fraternity, it is apparent how
such a charge of fraternity politics could be made.
Whether this was, indeed, an instance of fraternity
politics or not is beside the point. What matters is tfiat
such an issue could arise in the first place. It would
seem that our student government could he run in such
a manner that (+rages of this nature would not arise.

It is no disgrace to be poor. It is an error, but it is no disgrace.
So if your purse is empty, do not skulk and brood and hide
your head in shame. Stand tall. Admit your poverty. Admit it
freely and frankly and all kinds of good things will happen to
you. Take, for instance, the case of Blossom Sigafoos.
Blossom, an impecunious freshman at an Eastern girls'
college, was smart as a whip and round as a dumpling, and
scarcely a day went by when she didn't get invited to a party
weekend at one of the nearby men's schools.'But Blossom never
accepted. She did not have the rail fare; she did not have the
clothes. Weekend after weekend, while her classmates went
frolicking, Blossom sat alone, saved from utter despair only
by her pack of Marlboros, for even an exchequer as slian as
Blossom's can afford the joys of Marlboro—joys far beyond
their paltry price: rich, mellow.tobaccos, lovingly cured and
carefully packed, and an exclusive selectrate filter. Croesus
himself could not,buy a better cigarette!
However, Marlboro's most passionate admirers—among
whose number I am paid to count myself—would not claim that
Marlboro can entirely replace love and romance, and Blossom
/grew steadily moroser.

Then one day came a phone call from an intelligent sophomore named Tom O'Shanter at a nearby men's college. "Blossom," said Tom,"I want you to come down next week for the
barley festival, and I won't take no for an answer.!!
"No," said Blossom.
"Foolish girl," said Tom gently. "I know why you refuse
me. It is because you are poor, isn't it?"
"Yes;' said Blossom.
"I will send you a railroad ticket," said Tom. "Also a hardboiled egg in case you get hungry on the train."
"But I have nothing to wear," said Blossom.
Tom replied,"I will send you one suit of cashmere, two gowns
of lace, three slacks of velvet, four shoes of calf, five socks of
nylon, and a partridge in a pear tree."
"That is most kind," said Blossom, "but I fear I cannot
dance and enjoy myself while back home my poor lame brother
Tiny Tim lies abed."
"Send him to Mayo Brothers and put it on my tab,"said Tom.
"You are terribly decent," said Blossom, "but I cannot
come to your party because all the other girls at the party
will be from rich, distinguished families, and my father is but
a humble woodcutter."
"I will buy him Yosemite," said Tom.
"You have a great heart," said Blossom. "Hold the phone
while I ask our wise and kindly old Dean of Women whether it
is proper for me to accept all these gifts."
She went forthwith and asked the Dean of Women, and the
Dean of Women laid her wise and kindly old band on Blossom's
cheek and said,"Child, let not false pride rob you of happiness.
Accept these gifts from Tom."
"Oh, bless you, Wise and Kindly," breathed Blossom,
dropping grateful tears into the Dean's reticule. "I must run
and tell Tom."
"Yes, run, child," said thc Dean, a smile wrinkling her wise
and kindly old eyes."And ask him has he got an older brother."

reawakening of the right.

pound junior has proven himself a good passer and a fine
runner. Though he does not have

well and should keep Hopkins
busy all afternoon.

former halfback, Verdelli made
the switch to fullback this season when Dickinson lost its first
two fullbacks through graduation.

big line tomorrow, with the two

Henry Packard and Joe Lipinski,
both good. experienced veterans,

There's not much you can be
sure of nowadays. Steady Sam
Rayburn is fading fast; we're
threatened by nuclear war; and
now, of all things, Hopkins is
starting to win in Cross Country.
The Jays had a tidy 0-6 record
going into Saturday's triangular
meet with Swarthmore and Dickinson, but managed to outscore
the latter and finish second.
Then this Tuesday the runners
pulled another about-face and
trounced Washington College 19•
36.
Wins "Marred" Record
Although the nasty wins marred a previously unblemished log,
coach George Brown and his boys
breathed a sigh of relief. After
all, you can't keep up that sort
of amazing performance forever.
The harriers will travel to
Chester, Pa., tomorrow afternoon
to face Pennsylvania Military
Academy and Elizabethtown in
the final team meet of the season. Since the Jays have already
"ruined" things with two messy
wins, another won't hurt, so
things should prove to be fairly
interesting.
Impressive Showing
Tuesday's performance was
unquestionably the most impressive of the season, with Gerry
Miller, team captain Jim Fitzpatrick, and Steve Haust capturing the first three places. All
three runners have placed well
throughout most of the campaign, but this was the first time
that they have combined their
successful efforts in the same
meet.
The Mason-Dixon season will

come to a close next Saturday with the running of the
championships
at
individual
Washington College. Not much
is expected from the Hopkins
entries in that event.
The freshman harriers have already completed their season,
finishing in a blaze of glory with
a victory over Bainbridge Prep.

ball over to win. The entire second half, with the exception of
one series of plays, took place in
B.J.C. territory.

Cats are notoriously silent in their singularly feline way. But even the
most stealthily treading tomcat could take lessons from the men at
Ford Motor Company whose job it is to track down and suppress
unwanted noise in vehicles,.
At our Ford Research and Engineering Center in Dearborn, engineers
have created a unique room without echoes, virtually duplicating the
perfect stillness that exists miles above the earth's surface.
The "Silent Room", as we call it, is a chamber utilizing fiber-glass
wedges as sonic "blotters" to soak up noise emanating from subjects
undergoing developmental tests. In this acoustically sterile environ•.
ment, electronic instruments seek out the source of vibrations,
rattles, rumbles and squeaks so that they can be eliminated in
production.
This scientific approach to silence is but a tiny facet of the manysided program of pure and "applied research which goes on daily at
Ford Motor Company. It is another example of ford's leadership
through scientific research and engineering.
